explanation:
1) struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header (definition): needed to know the exact types and qualifiers of the members used in the for loop (header_size, kind, header, next). MISRA's rule depends on whether the loop counter (pos) and any objects accessed in the second/third clauses (pos and pos->next) are modifiable in the loop body — the struct definition shows if members are volatile/const, their types, and whether accessing pos->next reads an object that could be modified by other operations.  
2) struct MHD_Response (definition): needed to confirm the type/semantics of response->first_header (the initial value assigned to the loop counter). This lets us reason about aliasing/ownership (could body or called functions modify response->first_header or otherwise affect the loop counter) and whether first_header semantics could violate the rule.  
3) MHD_str_equal_caseless_bin_n_ (declaration/implementation): this function is called inside the loop body. MISRA requires that behaviour of called functions be considered when deciding whether objects used in the for clauses are modified by the loop body. We must inspect this function's prototype and implementation to ensure it has no persistent side effects that modify pos, pos->next, response->first_header, or any other object used in the for-condition/iteration expression.
